note: These are BRAND personas - people who follow Codaissance as a studio. Individual products have their own specific personas.

primary.name: Daniel
primary.title: The Quality-Conscious Developer

demographics.context: Works at a company but has strong opinions about tools, may have side projects or contribute to open source

beliefs: Most software is mediocre because incentives are wrong
Respects independent builders over VC-funded startups
behaviors: Evaluates tools on merit, not marketing hype
Reads source code, checks dependencies, reviews security
Would rather use fewer, better tools than many mediocre ones

pain_points: Good tools get acquired and ruined by new owners
'Free' tools harvest data or push premium aggressively
Enterprise software is bloated, slow, and overpriced
Hard to find tools built by people who actually use them
Security is usually an afterthought, not a foundation
trust_builders: No dark patterns or manipulative pricing
Products that solve real problems elegantly
Founder who clearly uses their own tools
messaging: Built by someone who actually uses it
Security and quality aren't features—they're foundations
No bloat, no dark patterns, no compromises

secondary.name: Mia
secondary.title: The Independent Builder / Solopreneur

demographics.context: Building own products or running small software business, 2-10 years into indie journey

beliefs: Independent builders can compete with big companies
Values the journey as much as the destination
behaviors: Studies how other indie builders operate
Budget-conscious but willing to pay for quality

pain_points: Hard to find role models building diverse product portfolios
Most indie hacker content focuses on one product or quick wins
Wants to see sustainable, quality-focused building approaches
Looking for inspiration beyond 'grow fast, exit fast'
trust_builders: Transparent sharing of process, decisions, and learnings
Quality products that prove the model works
Willingness to share both successes and failures
messaging: Building the tools we wish existed
Proving independent builders can deliver professional quality

tertiary.name: Alex
tertiary.title: The Security-Aware Professional

demographics.role: Works in or adjacent to security (AppSec, DevSecOps, security-conscious dev)
demographics.context: May work at security-focused company or regulated industry

beliefs: Security isn't a checkbox—it's a mindset
Most tools are built by people who don't understand threats
Values demonstrated security competence over claims

pain_points: Most tools treat security as an afterthought
Hard to find tools built by actual security professionals
trust_builders: Security built into architecture, not bolted on
Transparent about security approach and decisions
messaging: Built by an application security professional
Security isn't a feature—it's the foundation
Tools designed by someone who thinks like an attacker

quaternary.name: Patricia
quaternary.title: The Discerning Professional User

demographics.role: Professional in any field (educator, consultant, knowledge worker)
demographics.technical_level: Not necessarily technical but appreciates well-made tools

beliefs: Most software is designed for the company, not the user
Willing to pay premium for tools that respect them

pain_points: Software that's 'free' but wastes time with upsells and friction
Tools designed by people who don't use them
Features nobody asked for instead of fixing basic problems
trust_builders: Products that just work without fighting them
No manipulative patterns or hidden costs
Feeling like a valued customer, not a data source
messaging: Tools that respect your time and intelligence
Built to solve real problems, not create new ones

anti_personas.name: The Feature Counter
anti_personas.description: Wants the most features, not the best features. Compares tools by checkbox lists.
anti_personas.why_not: Codaissance builds focused tools, not Swiss Army knives

anti_personas.name: The Free-Only User
anti_personas.description: Refuses to pay for software regardless of value. Complains about any monetization.

anti_personas.name: The Hype Follower
anti_personas.description: Adopts tools based on Twitter buzz, not quality. Switches tools constantly.
anti_personas.why_not: Codaissance builds for long-term use, not hype cycles

anti_personas.name: The Enterprise Bureaucrat
anti_personas.description: Needs 50-page security questionnaires, SOC 2, ISO 27001, and committee approval.
anti_personas.why_not: Codaissance is indie—enterprise sales cycles don't fit the model

they_believe: Security should be default, not optional
Independent builders can compete with big companies
Software should respect users, not exploit them
The person building the tool should actually use it
they_respond_to: Products that solve real problems elegantly
Founders who eat their own cooking
